qas.question: How much money did the US loan to Britain after WW2?
When did Britain finish paying back the US loan?
When did the US make a large loan to Britain?
Though the US and the Soviet Union were both against colonialism, what was the US more afraid of?
How many people outside the UK were under British rule in 1945?

context: Though Britain and the empire emerged victorious from the Second World War, the effects of the conflict were profound, both at home and abroad. Much of Europe, a continent that had dominated the world for several centuries, was in ruins, and host to the armies of the United States and the Soviet Union, who now held the balance of global power. Britain was left essentially bankrupt, with insolvency only averted in <a2_0>1946<a2_0/> after the negotiation of a <a0_0>$US 4.33 billion<a0_0/> loan (US$56 billion in 2012) from the United States, the last instalment of which was repaid in <a1_0>2006<a1_0/>. At the same time, anti-colonial movements were on the rise in the colonies of European nations. The situation was complicated further by the increasing Cold War rivalry of the United States and the Soviet Union. In principle, both nations were opposed to European colonialism. In practice, however, American anti-<a3_0>communism<a3_0/> prevailed over anti-imperialism, and therefore the United States supported the continued existence of the British Empire to keep Communist expansion in check. The "wind of change" ultimately meant that the British Empire's days were numbered, and on the whole, Britain adopted a policy of peaceful disengagement from its colonies once stable, non-Communist governments were available to transfer power to. This was in contrast to other European powers such as France and Portugal, which waged costly and ultimately unsuccessful wars to keep their empires intact. Between 1945 and 1965, the number of people under British rule outside the UK itself fell from <a4_0>700 million<a4_0/> to five million, three million of whom were in Hong Kong.
